Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
4/28/2023. An exit confernce occurred with you on . Due to the violations of applicable
licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 248-860-0787.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she
has a right to have his or her written response included
as an attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of
this rule.
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social
services worker that has children placed in the home
Two of three special investigations reviewed did not show documentation of (a)-(c)
as required by the rule.
(c) Is a Repeat Violation Renewal 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12
months before placement or a new physical examination
2

shall be completed within 30 calendar days after
placement.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of an
annual medical examination which was due by 4/10/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement
to a youth before placement in independent living.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation that a copy of the agency's program statement was provided to the
youth.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency’s policies and procedures
required by this rule.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation that a copy of the agency's policy and procedures were provided to
the youth.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before
a youth is placed in independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements
for the specific program the youth is being placed into.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
3

(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before
a youth is placed in independent living:
(e) An evaluation of a youth’s need for supervision
and a plan for providing the level of supervision
determined necessary.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of (e) are required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before
a youth is placed in independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth’s
housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is
available.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of (f) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following
information and documentation, which shall be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support
sufficient to meet the youth’s housing, clothing, food, and
miscellaneous expenses.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
consistent quarterly documentation of proof of financial support as required by the
rule. Proof was not documented between August 2022 and March 2023.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following
information and documentation, which shall be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
4

(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth’s
biological children or a clear explanation why this is not
possible or appropriate.
One of three independent living youth records reviewed did not show that the youth
signed the 4/22/2022- 7/15/2022 treatment plan. Which related to one of 11
independent living youth service plans reviewed.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract
between the youth and the agency specifying all of the
following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of an initial mutually agreed upon contract.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The contract shall
be reviewed and updated at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
Two of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of an updated contract for October
2022 and January 2023.
• A second record did not show documentation of an independent living
contract signed by the agency and youth after 12/17/2021 and before
4/14/2023.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
FOM 722-6 B Family Team Meeting.
5

FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents,
caretakers, foster parents, children, youth, and may
also include extended family, friends, neighbors,
community-based service providers, community
representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the
family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting Certain
circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed, and three of three independent
living youth records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One open foster child record did not show documentation of an FTM for the
child’s 11/10/2022-2/1/2023 Updated Service Plan (USP). Additionally, this
record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for a reported 7/15/2022
FTM.
• A second open foster child record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 10/18/2022-11/16/2022 Initial Service Plan (ISP).
• The first of the open independent living youth records did not show
documentation of an FTM for the youth’s 12/31/2022-3/23/2023 USP.
• A second open independent living youth record did not show documentation
of an FTM for the youth’s 10/25/2022-1/17/2023 USP.
• A third open independent living youth record did not show documentation of
an FTM for the youth’s 4/22/2022-7/15/2022, 7/16/202022-10/6/2022 USP or
and next two USPs. An FTM was documented for 10/26/2022, 2/1/2023 and
4/7/2023, all of which were after the respective USP period.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2022, Interim 2021.
FOM 801-3 Medical Passport.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed documentation of a
December 2022 and March 2023 medical passport which did not reflect all of the
child’s medical information shown in the system for the respective time period.
6

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
Nothing this inspection.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
FOM 722-D Treatment plan- Agreement and Signature.
The agency was advised if it must mail the treatment plan to a parent or if the parent
refuses to sign the treatment plan, documenting the mailing and refusal date on the
treatment plan may aid it in showing compliance to the standard.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period. The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2022
Renewal Insepction where the agency received the following violations:
• R400.12212(3)(a) Personnnel records.
• MCL 722.120(3) Investigation, Inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports….
• R400.12324(8) Reevaluation.
• R400.12327(5)(d),(e) Special evaluation.
• R400.12327(6)(a) Special evaluation.
• R400.12405(3) Change of placement.
• R400.413(1)(f)(i) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12418(2)(b) Development of service plans.
• R400.12502(2) Program statement.
• R400.12503(3) Policy & procedures.
• R400.12504(1) Eligibility requirements.
• R400.12504(2) Eligibility requirements.
• R400.12510(1)(a) Independent living contract.
• R400.12510(2) Independent living contract.
• ISEP 6.19 (50(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content(commitment
69).
• FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting
7

• FOM 722-8 Case Service plans-Overview, Type, And Timeframes-
Supervisor Approval.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary-Completion
Requirements.
• FOM 801-3 Medical Passport.
The agency made progress with completion of this corrective plan as indicated by
the reduced number of citations in this inspection report. The agency provided:
proof of training or policy reviews it indicated it would complete( Independent living
requirements, family team meetings, medical passports, review of it’s renewal
inspection); samples of emails and outlook calendar assistance reminders to
workers related to reports, medical/dental due dates and timesframes; checklists
used to aid workers related to what must be completed within the first 30 days of a
case, for the initial service plan, for the updated service plan, for replacement of a
child, and related to foster care case closure. The agency also provided samples
of supervision notes showing discusses with workers related to the status of tasks
on cases. Notwithstanding these tools and efforts, the agency was not totally
successful with compliance in all areas. The agency received repeat violations as
indicated earlier in this inspection report.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator's report dated 5/3/2023 was completed as required. No
concerns were indicated related to its completion.
Financial Overview
Not applicable this is a Department of Health and Human Services local office
agency.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were completed, and no concerns were indicated.
I interviewed one independent living youth, and no concerns were reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
No concerns were observed related to a walkthrough of the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts this inspection.
RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
